The number of people facing insufficient food consumption spiked sharply after the events of August 2021. Since then, some nine in ten households have faced insufficient food consumption each month.
The food security situation marginally improved from the previous month, from 13 percent in January 2023 to 11 percent in February 2023. Food security varied in divisions with an increasing trend.

Food insecurity worsened in Vanuatu in Q1-2 of 2022 (at 25-30 percent), but improved to 15 percent by Q3. In Kiribati, there has been little change, with 7 percent of the population food insecure in Q3. Fiji saw a slight improvement, with 1 percent food insecure.

*Findings for the Pacific are available regularly through the dashboard, rather than a report.
Food insecurity improved in the last few months of 2022, from 21 percent in August to 15 percent in December. Food insecurity is slightly worse in rural areas.

Almost one in seven households (13.5 percent) were food insecure in February/March 2023. This has remained relatively stable in recent months, but could worsen with inflation remaining at record highs.
A third of the population was food insecure in January 2023. Food insecurity levels have remained consistently over 30 percent each month since remote food security monitoring began in mid-2022.
About one in four households are food insecure, with the states of Chin, Kayah, Kayin, Rakhine, and Sagaing having the worst food security outcomes across all indicators.
The proportion of people facing insufficient food consumption in October (18 percent) had worsened by about 5 percentage points compared with June 2022.
One in ten households were food-insecure (11 percent) in October. While food consumption is relatively good, there is a notably high reliance on coping strategies. Trends are not yet available.
Nearly one-fifth (18 percent) of households in Tajikistan were food-insecure in September. Compared to May, the proportion of food-insecure households has slightly improved, by 3 percentage points.

300,000 people, or 22 percent of the population, have plunged into food insecurity due to high food prices, reduced purchasing power, persistent impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the recent flooding.
